Let me be perfectly clear: I did not ask for this. I was 72 hours away from presenting the SmoothCurrent‚Ñ¢ 9000 ‚Äî a smart blender that would have reduced every American household's energy bill by 31%. Thirty-one percent. I had the math. I had the prototype. I had a slot at the Boise Energy Summit. What I did not have was a contingency plan for a 14-pound Persian with a vendetta and a talent for finding power cables.

At 2:47 PM on March 14th, 2024, Marshmallow unplugged the SmoothCurrent during a live demo. The cascade failure knocked out power to six city blocks. Channel 7 called it "The Boise Blender Blackout." The Electrical Engineering Society called it "grounds for permanent expulsion." I call it premeditated sabotage by an animal with a 2-gram brain and a grudge about being switched to the grain-free kibble.

Three months later, I emerged from my converted Cold War bunker (previously used as a yarn storage facility by the previous owner, a situation I have chosen to lean into rather than fight) with PurrfectFlow. If cats are going to destroy everything we build, then we need a project management platform that accounts for the destruction. Every deadline in PurrfectFlow has a built-in "Marshmallow Buffer" ‚Äî an automatic 3-day extension triggered by feline interference events. Every file is backed up to a location that Marshmallow cannot physically sit on (I am still searching for such a location).

I drink nine cups of coffee a day. The bunker smells like yarn and server heat. Marshmallow is asleep on the kill switch right now ‚Äî you can see her on the live cam below. I have accepted that I cannot defeat her. But I can build software that survives her. That's the promise. That's PurrfectFlow.

Zero cat-interference guaranteed.*

‚Äî Brenda, from the bunker, 3:41 AM

* This is not true. We have experienced 847 cat-interference events in the last 90 days. Legal made me add this footnote.

Frequently Asked Questions

FAQ

Questions we receive constantly, mostly about the cat.

Yes. Genuinely, yes. Brenda is a brilliant engineer. The Kanban boards are excellent. The Gantt charts are responsive and intuitive. The real-time collaboration features rival Asana. The problem is that a Persian cat has root access to the production database and there is nothing anyone can do about it. But the software itself? Chef's kiss.

During an early build, Brenda left her workstation unlocked while making her 6th coffee of the morning. Marshmallow walked across the keyboard and, through what Brenda describes as "either pure chance or evidence of a calculating intelligence that haunts me to this day," created a superadmin account with the password "meowmeowmeowmeow." Attempts to revoke access have failed because Marshmallow has also enabled two-factor authentication tied to a phone that she hid somewhere in the bunker. We can hear it vibrate sometimes.

Then we all perish. But on the bright side, Marshmallow will finally have someone to cuddle with. Our disaster recovery plan (codename: Operation Red Dot) involves a laser pointer, three cans of tuna, and Gerald. We have rehearsed this drill 14 times. It has never worked. Gerald is very tired.

Gerald is not available for social engagements. Gerald is running. Gerald is always running. If you are on the Catnap Pro plan or above, Gerald will deliver your notifications personally and you may exchange brief pleasantries, but please do not attempt to engage Gerald in extended conversation as this reduces his daily delivery capacity by approximately 12 notifications. If you would like to send Gerald a granola bar, please mail it to PurrfectFlow HQ, Bunker Unit 3, Boise, ID. He will find it.

We do not discuss the SmoothCurrent‚Ñ¢ 9000. Brenda's therapist has advised against it. What we will say is that US Patents #11,847,229 and #11,847,230 remain valid and describe a "multi-phase domestic energy recapture system utilizing centrifugal blade harmonics" that would have changed the world. All prototypes are currently buried in an undisclosed location. Marshmallow knows where. She visits them sometimes. We don't know why.

Define "okay." Brenda is alive. Brenda is productive. Brenda has shipped 847 features in the last 6 months. Brenda also talks to a cactus named Kevin and has installed 16 security cameras pointed at a single cat. Brenda sleeps 2 hours a night, subsists on a diet of discount coffee and spite, and refers to Marshmallow exclusively as "the entity" in formal communications. Is Brenda okay? Brenda is building something. That has to count for something.
